Chapter on Benefiting the World, Part 1, Chapter 9, Part 1, 14 main biographies with 2 additional biographies. Biography of Fa Cheng of Chang'an in the Zhou Dynasty. Shi Fa Cheng, originally surnamed Wang, named Shou Shen, served as a censor.
During Empress Wu's reign, she was suspicious and believed in cruel officials who framed him, so he avoided the court and begged to become a monk.
He was strict in his practice and diligent in guiding others. His reputation spread like an echo, and his conduct was lofty and sincere.

During the Longshuo era, he dug a large canal in the western market of Chang'an, calling it the Sea Pond. He branched off the Yong'an Canal to supply it, making it a place for releasing living creatures.
The Buddha's residence and sutra pavilion on the pond were all built by him.
When digging the pond, they found an ancient stone with an inscription saying, After a hundred years of being a market, it will become a pond.
From the time of the Sui Dynasty establishing the capital and setting up the market, it had been exactly a hundred years.
In the second year of Yifeng, those who observed the qi said:
There is a strange qi in this ward.
The emperor ordered it to be dug up, and they found a stone casket, inside of which were stored over ten thousand grains of Buddha relics, their light and color brilliant and solid.
The emperor ordered a Guangzhai Temple to be built at this place, and the relics were then distributed to the capital temples and various prefectures, with forty-nine grains each.
Empress Wu Zetian began to build a seven-jeweled platform here, and the temple's name was changed accordingly. Gong Cheng lived there.
He carried out his exhortations, often taking promoting blessings as his own responsibility.
Shi Yefang, the Dharma grandson of Chan Master Jiemo, was from Taiyuan.

His body was seven feet and five inches tall, with an ancient appearance, towering, hanging hands passing his knees, eyebrows several inches long, and eyes with double pupils, making people look at him with awe.
He never tired of paying respects and chanting, following the lofty steps of Zhide, his actions in accord with the formless, not abandoning benefiting beings, and again cultivating the Brahma palace.

The Biography of Guangyi of Qinglong Temple in the Upper Capital of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Guangyi of Qinglong Temple in the Upper Capital of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Guangyi, whose surname was Li, was originally a member of the Tang imperial clan.
His father, King Langya, raised troops with the King of Yue to restore the imperial way of the previous dynasty, but failed. Empress Wu's clan executed them, leaving no survivors.
Yi Fang was still in swaddling clothes when his wet nurse carried him to escape.
Several years later, Empress Wu secretly heard that King Langya had a son in the common people and searched for him with increasing urgency.
The wet nurse was about to reach the border of Fufeng when she sold her labor to support herself.
Yi was eight years old, with an extraordinary appearance and extraordinary spiritual understanding.
The wet nurse suspected that she would be ruined by judging by appearance, and was extremely worried and suspicious.
She then made a padded jacket and placed money in the waist and abdomen, under the mulberry forest, telling him to leave.
The edict searches without leniency. I fear we will both die, which will not benefit the matter.
You are intelligent and will surely be able to stand on your own.
Perhaps one day you will be rich and noble, do not forget this old woman.
After saying this, they cried facing each other.
The mother was so distraught that she passed away.
Yi wandered aimlessly and ended up at an inn, playing with a group of children.

The wife of the county magistrate went to her husband's residence and, just as she was resting, she saw Yi and the others playing there, with Yi's appearance being particularly outstanding. She felt pity for him.
She called out to him and said:
Where is the young master's home? Why are you wandering here alone?
Yi lied and said:
The estate is next to here. Sometimes I come to play.
The wife fed him and gave him money. He then untied his clothes and put the money inside.
At dusk, he followed a path and left, intending to go to a village.
He encountered an old monk who called out:
You little one, now that your family has been destroyed, where are you going?
Yi was startled and stood there. The old monk said again:
Leaving home is carefree and without worries. Little one, do you want to do it?ğŸ”½Yi said:
Yes.
It is what I have always wished for.

The old monk then took his hand to the shade of a large tree, had him pay homage to the Buddhas of the ten directions, and take refuge in the eternally abiding Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha. He then shaved his head.
He also took out a kÄá¹£Äya robe and put it on him, fitting both small and large.
His holding and covering was like a bhiká¹£u who had been ordained for several years.
The old monk was delighted and said:
This is due to habitual tendencies. You are good at upholding the monastic practices.
He then pointed to the northeast and said:
Several li from here there is a monastery. Go straight there and tell the abbot that I have sent you to be his disciple.
After saying this, the old monk suddenly disappeared, and only then did he realize he was a holy monk.
Following his words, he rushed there, and the abbot was startled by his words, and so kept him.
After ten years or so, Yi had thoroughly understood the sÅ«tras and vinaya, and was skilled in meditation.
When the Zhongzong Emperor ascended the throne, the Tang Dynasty was revived. The emperor ordered the search for the descendants of the Langya Wang family. Yiguang told the monks in the temple.
At that time, the assembly was greatly shocked. He then went to Fufeng and met with Li Shijun, who was Yiguang's uncle.
Seeing him, he was both sad and happy. He then took him in and reported to the court, firmly requesting that he not be allowed to leave.
Shijun had a daughter who was of the same age. When she saw Yiguang, she was delighted and wished to express her feelings.
Yiguang feared being overwhelmed and avoided her.
Another day, Shijun's wife brought out her daughter, who was gorgeously dressed and had many attendants. She came and pressed him.
Yiguang firmly rejected her in many ways, but in the end, he did not want to comply. He lied and said:
My body is unclean. Please take a bath and wait for my command.
The daughter agreed and then had him prepare a bath. When the daughter came out, she locked the door.
The woman tried to push the door open but couldn't get in. She peered through the window and saw him holding a razor. She said to herself:
Because of this organ, I am oppressed by desire. If I remove it now, what will oppress me?
The woman feared he would stop her, but he couldn't. She then cut off his genitals and threw them on the ground.
Yu was also in a daze, and the door was still closed.
Soon the magistrate and his wife arrived together. The woman told the truth in detail, and they finally broke down the door to look.

He gradually regained consciousness. The doctor and workers carried him back to the sericulture room, burned the ground with fire, doused it with strong liquor, sat him on it, and applied ointment to him.
After more than a month, the wound healed. The magistrate reported that Yu was the prince of Langya.
By imperial decree, he was placed on a post-horse and sent to the capital. He was granted an audience and comforted. He was generously rewarded. The edict ordered him to inherit his father's title.
Yu earnestly declined, vowing to become a monk. He was determined and unshakable.
The Emperor Zhongzong ordered him to lead his disciples and establish a hermitage, freely spreading the Dharma.
Yixing preferred Zhongnan Mountain and lived at Faxing Temple.
At the mouths of various valleys, he built huts and hermitages, totaling dozens of places. His reputation spread far and his talks moved people.

Sometimes when walking in the mountains for ten miles, thousands or hundreds of monks and laypeople would always accompany him, welcoming and serving him, even more than for powerful officials and nobles.
Yixing always lived in quiet meditation, sometimes speaking of future events to determine good or bad, never missing the mark, and people increasingly turned to him.
On the twenty-third day of the sixth month in the twenty-third year of Kaiyuan, he first entrusted his disciples, saying:
You should be careful to protect body and speech, and not engage in noisy clamor.
The meaning of the Patriarch's teaching is nothing else; when still, the true Dharma appears before you.
Apart from this, all other teachings are done out of necessity.
His words were extremely impassioned.
He then lay down with his head to the north, resting his cheek on his arm, and passed away while sitting on the mat - this was a sign of his great nirvana.
He left instructions to be buried south of Shaoling Original, so they dug a cave in the original and sealed it.
When the coffin was opened, strange fragrances wafted, and his appearance was as if alive.
When the ancestral carriage left the city, hundreds of white cranes cried out in the sky, and colorful clouds covered the carriage for dozens of li.
Monks and laypeople wailed, and many held mourning clothes.
At the place where he was buried, Tianbao Temple was built, and his disciples all stayed behind to guard it.

The Biography of Shi Zizhao of Dabi Temple in Zhending Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Zizhao of Dabi Temple in Zhending Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Zizhao was a person from Wangdu in Boling.
From a young age, he detested worldly ways, and suddenly told his parents:
I enjoy following the Buddha to seek liberation from the world.
His parents were shocked and scolded him to leave.
However, without shame or embarrassment, he bowed twice and requested to receive the precepts. He was then forced to take the precepts from Zhiqin of Kaigen Temple in the same prefecture.
Zhiqin observed that his aspirations were extraordinary and gave him the name Zizhao.
He instructed him, saying:
You should hear the name and contemplate the meaning.
He replied:
The Buddha's teachings arise from conditions. I only listen to the clear teachings.
Afterward, he recited the sutras and passed the test, receiving the precepts.
In the second year of Zhide, when he was of age, he received the full precepts at Zhenzhou.
He then went to Chanfa Temple in Lingshou County to study the Vinaya scriptures and treatises. He diligently practiced for nine years and penetrated their subtleties.
He then said, I should enter the Taihang Mountains, build a thatched hut on a large rock, and make a small stream my pure abode. Wouldn't that be delightful?

On the last day of the ninth month of the first year of Dali, he went to the border of Pingshan County and found a mountain temple in a dense forest. It was exactly as he had wished. He secluded himself and enjoyed the solitude.
By the second year, in the fifth month, the sky was parched by drought. Jue then walked barefoot, and in winter he bared his right shoulder.
In the dense forests and valleys, tigers, wolves, and leopards left tracks overlapping.
He only picked fruits and vegetables, eating once at noon.
At that time, the military commissioner of Hengyang, Zhang Jun, suffered from the hot and dry weather. Hearing of Jue's ascetic practice, he personally entered the mountain to request rain.
Zhang said to him:
I have no political skills, causing the people to suffer for three years of drought. Blaming myself for the hardship, I have nothing to make up for it.
Some say that the dragon kings often rely on the master to listen to the Dharma, forgetting to provide rain.
I wish the master would make a vow to save from the drought, like the white water.
If you think of the people, please stop your meditation and briefly enter the military camp.
Jue then earnestly appealed to the dragons and spirits. Before the hour had passed, the sky suddenly rained heavily, lasting for two watches.
Zhang Shuai's devotion was diligent and sincere, like a filial child serving his parents.
Since Jue first entered the Dharma, he studied the vows of all Buddhas in the cause, which also numbered forty-nine.
His first vow:
To follow Bodhisattva MahÄkaruá¹‡ika, the next vow:
To create and cast an image of MahÄkaruá¹‡ika.
When he spoke, the sound responded, and donations gathered. Using red gold, he cast it to a height of forty-nine feet, with the appearance of a deity, complete eyes and arms.
After another year, the temple was also completed, which is perhaps the large temple on the west side of the city.

He then recited in front of the altar until three in the morning, when he saw two paths of divine light, with golden color in the middle. In the radiance, he saw AmitÄbha Buddha, with AvalokiteÅ›vara and MahÄsthÄmaprÄpta flanking him on the left and right. The Buddha extended his golden arm and called out to Jue, gradually descending on clouds, and patted his head, saying:
Uphold your vow without wavering, do not be lax, benefiting beings is foremost.
You go ahead, I will follow, I will do as you wish.
After speaking, the clouds dispersed, and there was no trace left.
Jue, having fulfilled his vow, returned to the mountains and forests to choose a place to pass away.
On the night of the first day of the second month in the eleventh year of the Zhenyuan era, a divine being appeared, showing only half of his body, resembling the form of VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a, and said:
The master will attain nirvana this year.
He raised his hand and thanked the divine being, saying:
The fixed division of coming and going, I have received your instruction.
On the fourteenth day of the sixth month of that year, he suddenly passed into nirvana.

The disciples wanted to carry his sacred coffin back to the mountain temple, but the people of the prefecture and state kept him, and he finally passed away at the southern retreat of the Great Compassion Temple.
That was on the eighth day of the fourth month in the thirteenth year.

The great compassion of this statue is a strange event in Hengyang. Its responsive manifestations are secretly communicated. In the beginning of the Zhou Xien De era, an edict was issued to cast the nine prefectures' round laws, and copper statues from all over the country were uniformly destroyed.
At that time, the people of the state collectively raised money to redeem this statue, but it was not accepted. It was then melted in the furnace.
The people of Zhen Ding all grieved.

By the time of Emperor Taizu Shen De of the Song Dynasty, the statue was cast again by imperial order, to atone for the previous events.
Tang Dynasty, now the Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital, Biography of Huicun. The monk Huicun, whose surname was Yao, was a man from Huxiang.
He had a refined and bright nature and a loose and bright appearance.
In the first year of the Linde era of Emperor Gaozong, when he was ten years old, he had a lofty aspiration to leave the dust, but his parents often discouraged him.

His mind was like a mat, which could not be rolled up. His father pitied his wish and followed him to the Chan Master of the First Ancestor of Nanyue to receive the compassionate teachings. He was able to be intelligent and enjoy the taste of sutras, and was as silent as such.
By the time he reached adulthood, he received the complete precepts at Mount Yue Temple.
He specialized in protecting the precepts and was good at the Vinaya. He then stopped lecturing and focused on meritorious deeds.
His words responded like echoes, and the secular world followed his transformation.
He established things beyond partiality, and the scholars and common people respected him.

He then left the heavy lakes to travel to Jing and Ying, shook his staff in Jiangnan, and carried his bag to the banks of the Zhe River. His purpose was to encourage people to abandon the illness of stinginess.
Wherever he went, he built or repaired more than twenty temples, all of which were accomplished without taking credit for himself.
In the first year of the Longshi era of Empress Wu Zetian, he traveled to the north of the Yangtze River to spread the Dharma, but the conditions were not yet right.
In the first year of the Long'an era, he came to observe the Liang Garden. He stayed overnight at Fantai, looking up at the north bank of the river, there was a strange aura reaching to the sky.
The next morning he entered the city to search for it and found it in the northwest garden pond of the residence of the Prefect of Xihe.

Yun walked to the shore and saw the reflection of a heavenly palace in the rippling water, with towering pavilions and terraces, strings of pearls, and colorful doors and windows, with the images of the nine chambers winding like a thousand shapes - it was truly the palace of Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
Yun was overjoyed upon seeing this strange sight:
I have heard the Sutra of the Adornment of Wisdom say:
'The palace shadows appear on the ground of lapis lazuli,' this is an inconceivable realm.
Now I will definitely build a Buddhist palace to repay the auspicious signs.
So he hung his staff at Anye Temple.

In the second year of Shenlong, the year of bingwu, he went to Baocheng Temple in the affiliated county of Puyang and vowed to copy a Maitreya image for the country, raising it to a height of one zhang and eight chi, and soliciting people to donate red gold.
At that time, donors poured in, and in a short while, it was like a hill.
He then shook his purse and measured the skilled craftsmen, and in one casting, he successfully completed it, with a strange and unusual appearance.
It was almost the fourth year of Jinglong, the year of gengxu, the sixth month, when King Wen abdicated the throne to Ruizong, his uncle.
In the first year of Jingyun, he built a separate hall to the south of the east corridor of the temple to enshrine the holy image.
When he first said to prepare the materials and discuss the construction, the donors had various opinions, and it was not completed.
In the second year, the year of xinhai, he bought the house of Zheng Jing, the clerk of Xin'an, to the north of the sutra repository of Fuhui Temple.

When they were about to start construction, they dug up an ancient stele, which recorded the establishment of the Jian Guo Temple in the 6th year of Tian Bao of the Northern Qi, in the year of Yi Hai. It was established by Emperor Wen Xuan, the son of Gao Huan.
Those who saw it all marveled and sighed, like Shariputra feeling pity for the ant hill.

The Commissioner of Investigation praised it as extraordinary twice, and thus followed this record, changing Fu Hui to Jian Guo Temple, welcoming and taking the sacred image of An Ye and the temple materials to the temple.

On the 13th day of the 5th month in the 1st year of Tai Ji, the era was changed to Yan He. In this year, Wang Zhi Yin, the Minister of the Department of Punishments, became the Commissioner of Investigation and proclaimed the edict in the suburbs of Jun:
All temples without name tablets should be demolished, and all bronze and iron Buddha images should be collected into nearby temples.
The cast image moved by Yun, as well as the construction of the temple, gate, and corridors, still lacked colorful decoration.
Encountering the new edict, the work was suspended.
Yun, in front of the Maitreya image, wept, burned incense, and made a heavy vow, saying:
If there is a karmic connection with this, it will manifest auspicious omens to enlighten the minds of the masses.
Shortly after, a golden light emitted from the top of the statue, illuminating the heavens and earth. All the citizens in the city marveled at the rarity.
At that time, those who slandered and reviled lost both eyes, and some had a tongue swelling a foot long.
The news spread far and near, and people came to pay homage, offering donations like mountains, thus completing the magnificent appearance.
The statue sits with legs pendant, and people bow their heads in reverence.

Those who have committed evil deeds look up to the statue and repent, and those who suddenly lose their eyesight or have tongue curling pay homage. They all wish to become slaves of the temple, ringing the bell and sweeping the grounds.
The envoy Wang Zhi'im and Helan Wu jointly recorded the auspicious omens and reported them to the court.
The wise emperor secretly dreamed of it, and an edict was issued to change the signboard of Jian Guo to Xiang Guo - this is because the emperor was a king of Xiang when the dragon flew.
He also ordered Minggan, a monk of Foshoujiji Temple, to jointly inspect the merits and prevent the state and prefectures from being troubled.

Jia Zeng, a secretary in the Secretariat, Cui Zhuo, a senior administrator, Lu Yi, a court gentleman, and Cen Xi, a senior administrator and chief minister, all donated their salaries to create the conditions together - some initiating the initial aspiration, some providing external protection.

In the Xiantian era, he transmitted the Dharma to the Prince of Lu, and when Xuanzong ascended the throne, on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, the retired emperor bestowed the temple plaque. He ordered the monk Zhendi, two disciples, and one official to bring the imperial edict, banners, flowers, and the temple plaque to receive and hang them.

Yun's spiritual transformation of the Liang region, his body enjoying the blessed tree, the hundred years had a limit, the four characteristics interchanged, and he finally passed away in a separate courtyard of the temple.
He was buried east of the capital, and the stupa pavilion of the temple's estate still exists.
At that time, he was called the Patriarchal Master of Temple Construction.
After Yunchu's passing, in the fourth year of Tianbao, a great pavilion was built, called Paiyun.
In the Sui Zong Zhide years, the East Pagoda was built, called Puman, completed in the tenth year of the Dali era of Emperor Dezong of the Tang.
It is said that the monk who built the pagoda could manifest multiple bodies to spread the Dharma, and his level of attainment was difficult to fathom.
Manjushri and Vimalakirti were friends of the Prince's Mansion, and Wu Daozi painted and sculpted them.

In the fourteenth year of Kaiyuan, Xuanzong returned from a tour of the eastern mountains, and ordered Che Zhengdao to go to Khotan to copy the image of the Heavenly King, and paint it on the temple wall.
Monk Zhiyan raised funds to paint the Stages of Entry into the Way of the Three Vehicles on the north wall of the west storehouse, all of which are considered extraordinary.
The current halls and buildings were all built after a fire in the Dairong year, and were repaired by Emperor Taizu of the Song.
The wall paintings by Gao Yi, a Hanlin scholar, were considered the finest in calligraphy and painting at the time.
Biography of Xuanlan of Huayan Temple in Hangzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Xuanlan of Huayan Temple in Hangzhou, Tang Dynasty Huichang Shouru Shi Xuanlan, whose surname was Chu, was from Henan.
He settled in Qiantang and made it his home.
Xuanlan was born with a bright virtue and had a profound understanding of the truth, using it as the foundation for cultivating goodness.
From his first thought to leaving the family, he followed Master Huichang as his teacher.
Master Huichang's virtue was complete in all aspects, and he was respected by the assembly. He was old in age and respected in conduct, and had long been a teacher and model.
When he saw that Xuanlan did not contradict benevolence even for a moment, he told his disciples:
The supreme Way takes purity as its foundation.
If one can use their mind for a single thought, I have not seen anyone who is insufficient in their studies.
For a long time, there have been no true monks in the Jiangnan area. Could this son be the Dharma drum?
Allowing those far and near to hear it.
His being distinguished by the enlightened craftsmen was like this.

The original village had an old Huayan Temple, which was located near the tomb of Master Xuanli, the ancestor of the master. At that time, the Sui Dynasty was in decline, and the Dharma abode was dilapidated. The name was about to be buried and forgotten, and the traces were also temporarily abandoned.
In the early Tang Dynasty, believers were recruited to rebuild it.
In the Mingwen year, there was an imperial decree allowing the restoration of the original name, and the layout and system were expanded, and the foundation was also moved.
With the mountain behind and facing the water, the scenery is magnificent.
The master first took full precepts under Tianzhu, then became the abbot of Yixianju as the Saá¹ƒgha Recorders, and later became the abbot of Huayan with his advanced age.
The three temples were successively entrusted to the master, and the Way was everywhere, so the teachings were moved.
The master always took compassion for sentient beings as his responsibility, so he planned to make the connecting river in front of the temple into a pond for releasing living creatures.
At that time, the prefect Yuan Congli was inspired by this and deeply entered the gate of compassion, prohibiting fishing within six miles.
Sima Yang Min said he felt a dream, and it was expanded to ten li.

Lan also considered scriptures and images to be the most important, so he painted four images in front of the hall, with Maitreya at the head, and cast 350 golden bronze statues, with Amitabha at the head;

With such merits, he followed the present retribution - therefore, the king posthumously honored his ancestor as the Prefect of Hezhou;
The Right Attendant-in-Ordinary, Duke of Shu State, Wuliang, was Lan's eldest brother.
When Wuliang was studying, the dragon of Linping Lake appeared, and everyone went to see it, but Duke Shu calmly did not leave his desk, his bearing was like this.
In the early years of the Kaiyuan era, Duke Shu served as a lecturer, and the emperor appreciated him.
Returning to pay respects to the great grandmother, who was already in her twilight years, the brothers all had white hair. In the morning and evening, they only spoke the Dharma.
In the twenty-second year of Kaiyuan, Lan showed signs of illness and passed away at the temple he built in Linping. He was eighty-four years old.
Seng Mingliao, Dajue, Puxian, Shenman, and Huaisun all participated in the Dharma stream and revered the Dharma vessel, which was hidden under the base of Xilie Cave.
Xu Anzhen, the Vice Minister of the Ministry of Works, composed a stele inscription to praise his virtues.
Also, Shi Shouru of Aidu Temple in Minzhong was often involved in encouraging and guiding others. The people of Yue returned to him like clouds gathering.
He built a meditation hall to benefit the masses, with the urgency of benefiting others.

In the tenth year of Kaiyuan, he built a bathhouse at the temple. He was concerned that the terrain was steep and high, with clear springs below, and that the water wheel was useless, and the drawing of water was far away, which would be tiring in the end.
He thought about it but did not have a way to change it.

Suddenly one night, the water in the lower reaches suddenly dried up. Twenty-plus steps away from the location where the bathhouse was built, clear springs gushed forth. At that time, it was said to be the divine power working in secret, moving this spring.
The people of the seven Fujian provinces all returned to faith, and he passed away in the side room of the Warm Room.

Biography of Xuanlang of Qingtai Temple in Dongyang of the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Xuanlang of Qingtai Temple in Dongyang of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Xuanlang, whose courtesy name was Huiming, had the surname Fu.
His ancestors were from Puyang County, the descendants of Lord Zheng, the Prefect of Jiangxia.
During the Cao Wei period, they moved to the Jiangnan area to avoid the chaos. He was the sixth-generation grandson of Liang's great man Xi, and thus became a native of Wushang.
His mother, Lady Ge, had a dream of riding a sheep-drawn carriage flying through the sky before she became pregnant. She woke up feeling heavy.
From then on, she disliked the smell of meat and blood.
When she was about to give birth, she also felt as if she was in a dream.
After waking up, her mind felt light and her body felt at ease. The infant did not cry, but cooed and smiled.
At the age of nine, he left home. His teacher taught him the sutras, and he could memorize seven pages a day.
In the first year of Yirui, on the nineteenth day of the fifth month, he was ordained by imperial decree and assigned to Qingtai Temple.
At the age of twenty, he traveled far to study with Vinaya Master An of Guangzhou and received the full precepts.
He then studied the precepts and rituals.
He also extensively read the sutras and treatises, seeking out differences and similarities, especially the Nirvana Sutra.
He always regretted that although the ancient masters had written commentaries, their judgments were not fair.
In the past, at Miaoxi Temple in Kuaiji, he discussed the secret essentials with Chan Master Yinzong. Although they mutually expressed their understanding, the main points were not complete.
He heard that the Tiantai school could clarify the many obstacles and lead to the one principle. Therefore, he went to Tiangong Temple in Dongyang to study with Dharma Master Huixiang.
Huixiang inherited from Zhiwei of Kuazhou - at that time, it was rumored that Wei was the reincarnation of Xu Ling, a close disciple of Guanding.
Lang personally followed him, not caring about poverty and hardship.

He mastered the Lotus Sutra, the Vimalakirti Sutra, the Great Treatise on the Perfection of Wisdom, the Mohe Zhiguan, the Chanmen, and so on. He thoroughly researched the teachings and traces of each school.

Later, he relied on Chan Master Gong to cultivate the methods of meditation again. He had a vast knowledge of Confucian classics and was also familiar with the teachings of Daoism. There was nothing he did not encompass.
Although he was well-versed in various views, he considered the Mohe Zhiguan to be the course for entering the Way and the domain for setting the mind at ease.

Although the myriad sages transmit their thoughts, he considered Avalokitesvara's compassion and wisdom to be a good ferry for practical conduct. He roamed his mind in the ten vehicles, contemplated the three contemplations, benefited beings with the four methods of conversion, and embodied the universality of the six identities.
Although he directed his mind beyond the realm of things and his body was weary of the human world, he abandoned his old dwelling and aspired to dwell in the forest.
There were only eighteen kinds of twelve dhutangas. He hid in the Zixi Rock and used it as his name.
He sat alone in a room for more than thirty years. He made clothes from hemp and filled his meals with coarse vegetables.
He had a vow to be reborn in Tuá¹£ita Palace, and must rely on meritorious deeds. He then built a temple wall and painted images of AvalokiteÅ›vara and Pindola.
